DirectedLouvainR 0.0.1
  • Reference
  • News

    Directed Lovain clustering

    directed_louvain.Rd

    Get partitions for a directed Lovain clustering for a graph.

    Usage

    directed_louvain(x, precision = 0.0001, gamma = 1.0, renumbering = FALSE,
                 randomized = TRUE, level = "final", verbose = FALSE)

    Arguments

    x

    Either an igraph object from igraph package, an edge list (data.frame object) or an adjacency matrix (matrix object). If an edge list, then it can have either the first two columns, "from" and "to", or three columns, containing "weight".

    precision

    A numeric value representing the minimal improvement in modularity required to continue computing.

    gamma

    Size of the generated clusters and it is the resolution parameter. The relative significance of intra-community edges is scaled. Smaller clusters are associated with a higher gamma and larger clusters with a lower one. The default is for the original modularity definition and equal to 1.

    renumbering

    logical object restarting partition numbering from 1, until the maximum number of communities detected. The default is FALSE, corresponding to the order that they are detected.

    randomized

    logical object for randomized node updates, escaping locally optimal solutions. It means allowing to shuffle the order in which nodes are considered for moves. The default is TRUE, meaning randomized node updates.

    level

    Either character or integer object for controlling the number of levels (steps) of the algorithm. level = "final" means that the final level is returned, according to the precision above. If level = 1, then the first level (step) of the algorithm is returned, if level = 2, then the second level (step) etc. The default is "final".

    verbose

    logical object for printing additional information on console.

    Details

    Algorithm of directed Louvain algorithm, utilizing the directed modularity definition, as described in Dugué and Perez (2015, 2022). This implementation has taken parts of code from the supplementary code for the above paper, located in
    https://github.com/nicolasdugue/DirectedLouvain.

    directed_louvain refers to a more R-friendly version for the inputs. The internal
    DirectedLouvainR:::directed_louvain_fast accepts for x a matrix object with two first columns as the node IDs and the third optional the weights. DirectedLouvainR:::directed_louvain_fast is not listed here, because its inputs are not normalized and so its use is more "dangerous", but it is a bit faster because of the lack of pre-processing and IDs are advised to start from 1 until the number of nodes.

    Value

    Partition label number per node.

    References

    Dugué, N., & Perez, A. (2022). Direction matters in complex networks: A theoretical and applied study for greedy modularity optimization. Physica A: Statistical Mechanics and its Applications, 603, 127798. doi:10.1016/j.physa.2022.127798

    Dugué, N., & Perez, A. (2015). Directed Louvain: maximizing modularity in directed networks (Doctoral dissertation, Université d'Orléans).

    See also

    directed_modularity

    Examples

    # Edge list as data.frame
el <- data.frame(
  from   = c(1, 2, 3),
  to     = c(2, 3, 1),
  weight = c(1, 2, 3)
)

directed_louvain(el)
#> 1 2 3 
#> 1 1 1 

# Edge list as data.frame
elc <- data.frame(
  from   = c("A", "B", "C"),
  to     = c("B", "C", "A"),
  weight = c(1, 2, 3),
  stringsAsFactors = FALSE
)

directed_louvain(elc)
#> A B C 
#> 1 1 1 

# Adjacency matrix
adj <- matrix(c(0,1,0,
                0,0,2,
                3,0,0), nrow=3, byrow=TRUE)

rownames(adj) <- c("x","y","z")
colnames(adj) <- c("z","x","y")  # deliberately permuted

directed_louvain(adj)   # columns realigned to row order
#> x y z 
#> 1 2 3 

# igraph
library(igraph)

g <- make_ring(4)
E(g)$weight <- c(1,2,3,4)
V(g)$name <- c("n1","n2","n3","n4")

directed_louvain(g)
#> n1 n2 n3 n4 
#>  1  2  2  1
